title: SHOULD YOU USE A PLOW OR A ROTOTILLER? WE COMPARE THE TWO.

tasks.task: Drive the 1025R tractor with the attached Dirt Dog all-purpose plow for spring tilling.
subtasks: Position the tractor and plow in the field.
Secure the all-purpose plow to the subcompact tractor using the quick hitch.
Adjust the spring-loaded shanks for root and rock negotiation.
Execute multiple passes with the plow, matching tine alignment to rows.
Monitor ground conditions and adjust driving techniques (e.g., throttle, three-point leverage).
Evaluate performance, comparing results to a tiller for seedbed preparation.

tasks.task: Assemble and use the Rhino Hide canopy during tilling operations.
subtasks: Familiarize with the canopy's lightweight and quick-release mechanism.
Secure the canopy on and off the tractor as needed.
Assess the canopy's durability and performance in various terrain conditions.

tasks.task: Handle and maneuver the 1025R tractor in uneven, overgrown field.
subtasks: Navigate through rocks, roots, and autumn olive debris.
Manage the tractor's four-wheel drive disengagement and reengagement.

tasks.task: Operate the all-purpose plow to break up ground and prepare a seed bed.
subtasks: Determine appropriate pass depth and pressure for the equipment.
Address clod formation and other residue challenges during multiple passes.
Consider the potential impact of prior ground preparation (e.g., ripper used previously).

tasks.task: Compare the all-purpose plow's performance to a tiller (not part of the transcript but inferred for context).
subtasks: Identify key differences in tillage effectiveness and ground preparation quality.
Reflect on the versatility and limitations of the all-purpose plow versus specialized tillage tools.
